text: How does your team ensure that code remains maintainable over time?
category: Capabilities that enable a Climate for Learning

answers.text: We don’t have a defined approach
We use basic linting and formatting tools
We follow code review and documentation guidelines
We apply automated maintainability checks and refactoring practices
We have a culture of continuous refactoring and evolutionary architecture

text: How does your team ensure the quality and usefulness of documentation?
category: Capabilities that enable a Climate for Learning

answers.text: We rarely document or our documentation is outdated
We create basic documentation for major features when needed
We maintain up-to-date documentation for key systems and processes
We have standards for documentation quality and regularly review it
We treat documentation as a core deliverable, with clear ownership, continuous improvement, and easy discoverability

text: To what extent is your team empowered to choose the tools they use?
category: Capabilities that enable a Climate for Learning

answers.text: We have no say in tool selection and must use what is mandated
We can suggest tools, but adoption requires lengthy approval
We can choose some tools within predefined organizational guidelines
We are free to choose most of our tools, with coordination for compatibility
We have full autonomy to choose and adapt our tools to meet our needs, while sharing best practices across teams

text: How would you describe your organization's culture in terms of trust, collaboration, and information sharing?
category: Capabilities that enable a Climate for Learning

answers.text: Our culture is low trust, with limited collaboration and information kept siloed
Some teams collaborate, but information is mostly shared on a need-to-know basis
We have a generally cooperative culture, but information flow can be inconsistent
We have high trust and open communication, with regular cross-team collaboration
We have a high-trust, generative culture where information flows freely, collaboration is the norm, and people feel safe to share ideas and learn from mistakes

text: How satisfied are you with your job and work environment?
category: Capabilities that enable a Climate for Learning

answers.text: I am generally dissatisfied with my job and work environment
I experience occasional satisfaction, but issues often outweigh the positives
I am mostly satisfied, though there are some recurring challenges
I am satisfied with my job, my work environment, and the support I receive
I am highly satisfied and feel motivated, supported, and fulfilled in my work

text: How would you describe your team's culture around learning and skill development?
category: Capabilities that enable a Climate for Learning

answers.text: Learning is not prioritized and rarely happens during work hours
Learning happens occasionally, but mostly driven by individual initiative
Learning is encouraged, with some structured opportunities provided
We actively support continuous learning with regular time and resources dedicated
We have a strong learning culture where continuous improvement, knowledge sharing, and experimentation are part of everyday work

text: How often does your team run experiments to improve processes, tools, or outcomes?
category: Capabilities that enable a Climate for Learning

answers.text: We rarely or never run experiments
We occasionally try new things, but without a structured approach
We experiment periodically and sometimes measure the results
We regularly run experiments with clear goals and evaluate outcomes
Experimentation is part of our culture, with frequent, data-driven trials that inform continuous improvement

text: How would you describe the leadership style in your organization?
category: Capabilities that enable a Climate for Learning

answers.text: Leaders focus mainly on tasks and short-term results, with little inspiration or vision
Leaders occasionally provide vision or motivation, but mostly manage day-to-day work
Leaders set a clear direction and provide support, but may not consistently inspire or challenge the team
Leaders inspire, motivate, and support growth, fostering a shared sense of purpose
Leaders consistently demonstrate transformational leadership—sharing a compelling vision, encouraging innovation, empowering people, and leading by example

text: How well does your organization support your well-being and work-life balance?
category: Capabilities that enable a Climate for Learning

answers.text: Well-being is not considered, and workloads are often unsustainable
Some attention is given to well-being, but long hours or stress are common
Well-being is valued, with occasional initiatives to support balance
Well-being is actively supported through policies, flexibility, and resources
Well-being is a core part of our culture, with sustainable workloads, strong support systems, and a healthy work-life balance

text: How effectively does your team practice continuous delivery?

answers.text: We deploy infrequently, with manual processes and long lead times
We have some automation, but releases still require significant manual effort
We deploy regularly with mostly automated pipelines, though some manual steps remain
We have fully automated pipelines and can deploy to production on demand
We practice true continuous delivery, deploying small changes frequently and safely with rapid feedback loops

text: How does your team manage database changes?

answers.text: Database changes are manual, risky, and often cause downtime
We have basic scripts for database changes, but testing is minimal
We version-control database changes and test them in non-production environments
We automate database change deployments with rollback strategies
We fully integrate automated, tested, and reversible database changes into our deployment pipeline

text: How automated are your deployment processes?

answers.text: Deployments are entirely manual and time-consuming
Some deployment steps are automated, but manual intervention is still required
Most deployment steps are automated, with occasional manual tasks
Deployments are fully automated and repeatable
Deployments are fully automated, fast, reliable, and can be triggered on demand with minimal risk

text: How flexible and on-demand is your infrastructure provisioning?

answers.text: Infrastructure is fixed, slow to provision, and requires manual setup
Some infrastructure can be provisioned through tickets or requests, but it’s still slow
We use some infrastructure-as-code or scripts to provision environments
We have automated, self-service infrastructure provisioning through infrastructure-as-code
Infrastructure is fully automated, self-service, scalable on demand, and integrated into our delivery pipeline

text: How independently can your team deliver and deploy changes without relying on other teams?

answers.text: We are highly dependent on other teams for most changes
We can make some changes independently, but often require coordination with others
We can deliver many changes on our own, but still have some key dependencies
We are largely independent, with minimal dependencies on other teams
We are fully autonomous, able to design, build, test, and deploy changes without external dependencies

text: How streamlined is your change approval process?

answers.text: Change approvals are slow, manual, and require multiple layers of review
Approvals are somewhat standardized but still require significant manual steps
We have clear approval guidelines and some automation in the process
Approvals are automated for low-risk changes and fast for others
We use automated, risk-based change approval with guardrails, enabling fast and safe deployments

text: How closely does your team follow trunk-based development practices?

answers.text: We work on long-lived branches that are merged infrequently
We merge branches occasionally, but integration is often slow and causes conflicts
We integrate changes into the main branch at least once a week
We integrate changes into the main branch at least once a day
We commit small, frequent changes directly to the trunk or use short-lived branches merged multiple times per day

text: How effectively does your team use version control for all production artifacts?

answers.text: We do not use version control consistently for our code or artifacts
We use version control for application code, but not for all artifacts
We version-control all code and some other production artifacts
We version-control all production artifacts, including code, configurations, and scripts
We version-control everything needed to recreate our environments, ensuring full reproducibility

text: How effectively does your team use visual management to track work and progress?

answers.text: We have little to no visual tracking of work
We use basic boards or lists, but they are often outdated or incomplete
We maintain visual boards that are generally up to date and visible to the team
We use well-maintained, visible boards that help manage flow and identify bottlenecks
We have highly visible, real-time visual management systems that guide decision-making, improve flow, and make work status clear to all stakeholders

text: How does your team manage work in progress (WIP) limits?

answers.text: We do not set or track WIP limits
We occasionally set WIP limits, but they are not consistently followed
We set WIP limits for some work items and review them periodically
We set and consistently enforce WIP limits to maintain flow
We actively manage and adjust WIP limits based on team capacity and flow metrics to optimize delivery

text: How consistently does your team work in small batches?

answers.text: We typically work on large batches that take weeks or months to complete
We sometimes break work into smaller pieces, but large batches are still common
We regularly work in moderately sized batches to reduce risk
We consistently work in small batches that can be delivered in days
We always work in very small batches, enabling rapid feedback, quick delivery, and minimal risk

text: How effectively does your team practice continuous integration?

answers.text: We integrate code infrequently, leading to large and risky merges
We integrate code occasionally, but with minimal automated testing
We integrate code at least daily, with automated builds and basic tests
We integrate code multiple times per day with comprehensive automated tests
We practice true continuous integration with frequent merges, fast automated feedback, and fixes for broken builds immediately prioritized

text: How frequently and effectively does your team gather and use customer feedback?

answers.text: We rarely gather customer feedback
We gather feedback occasionally, but it is not systematically used
We regularly gather feedback and sometimes use it to inform decisions
We gather feedback frequently and use it to guide product improvements
We have continuous feedback loops where customer input directly drives ongoing product and delivery decisions

text: How effectively does your team monitor systems and use observability to detect and resolve issues?

answers.text: We have little to no monitoring, and issues are often found by customers
We have basic monitoring, but it only covers some systems or key metrics
We have monitoring for most systems and use it to detect and troubleshoot issues
We have comprehensive monitoring and observability, enabling rapid detection and resolution
We have proactive, automated observability with actionable alerts and deep insights that prevent issues before they impact customers

text: How effectively does your team monitor system health and performance?

answers.text: We have little to no monitoring, and problems are usually reported by users
We have basic monitoring that covers only a few key systems or metrics
We monitor most systems and can detect many issues before they escalate
We have comprehensive, automated monitoring with clear alerting for critical issues
We have proactive monitoring across all systems, with intelligent alerts and actionable insights that help prevent incidents

text: How well is security integrated into your software delivery process?

answers.text: Security is handled separately and only at the end of development
Security reviews happen occasionally, often late in the process
Security is considered during development, with some automated checks
Security practices and tools are integrated throughout the development lifecycle
Security is pervasive, automated, and embedded in every stage of development, with a strong culture of shared responsibility

text: How effectively are failures detected and communicated to the right people?

answers.text: Failures are usually found by customers or go unnoticed for long periods
We sometimes detect failures internally, but alerts are inconsistent or delayed
We detect most failures internally and notify relevant people in a timely manner
We proactively detect and communicate failures quickly to the right stakeholders
We have automated, proactive failure detection and instant, targeted notifications that enable rapid response before customers are impacted

text: How effectively does your team use automated testing?

answers.text: We rely almost entirely on manual testing
We have some automated tests, but coverage is low and maintenance is inconsistent
We have a good level of automated test coverage for critical functionality
We have comprehensive automated tests across multiple levels (unit, integration, end-to-end)
We have extensive, reliable, and fast automated tests that run continuously and provide rapid feedback to prevent defects

text: How does your team manage test data for automated and manual testing?

answers.text: Test data is created manually and inconsistently, often slowing down testing
We have some shared test data sets, but they are hard to maintain or reuse
We maintain version-controlled test data for key scenarios
We have automated processes for creating, managing, and refreshing test data
We manage test data automatically, with self-service, on-demand generation and anonymization that supports fast, reliable, and compliant testing

text: How visible is work across your entire value stream, from idea to delivery?

answers.text: Work is largely invisible beyond individual teams or functions
Some work is tracked across stages, but visibility is fragmented
We have tools or dashboards showing work across most of the value stream
We have clear, real-time visibility into work across the entire value stream
We have full, real-time transparency across the value stream, enabling data-driven decisions and continuous improvement
